headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Cows to Play a Part in Emissions Solution; Student Loan Forgiveness Struck Down; Questions around Same-Sex Wedding Website Ruling. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: PHIL MATTINGLY, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Welcome back.Cows and livestock are major contributors to carbon emissions, but now some scientists are saying, not so fast, and arguing cows, in fact, can actually be part of the solution.

utterances.speaker: AUDIE CORNISH, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: According to the Food and Agriculture Organization, livestock farming accounts for more than 14 percent of man-made emissions. Researchers, however, say if farmers change the way their cows graze, it could make a drastic difference.CNN's chief climate correspondent Bill Weir is here. And, Bill, what needs to happen?

utterances.speaker: BILL WEIR, CNN CHIEF CLIMATE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, these guys would say, farmers need to get -- fall back in love with mother nature and be closer to her than their fertilizer salesman. This is basically a style of farming that was common across humanity up until World War II, but it's really about letting nature do the work and taking influence from some very powerful models.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) WEIR (voice over): In the beginning was the buffalo. Tens of millions of them, wandering the land, munching wild grasses, and using poop and hooves to create rich, fertile soil up to 15-feet deep. WEIR (on camera): Look at this!

utterances.speaker: BYCK
utterances.sentences: Well, so adaptive multi-paddock grazing, amp grazing, is a way that mimics the way bison have moved across the Great Plains. And so it's really about the animals hit an area really hard and then they leave it for a long time.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Peter Byck is a professor at Arizona State University. And he believes that if enough beef and dairy operations copy this simple hack, cattle could actually become an ally in the fight against climate change.

utterances.speaker: BYCK
utterances.sentences: I anticipate we'll get a lot of pushback because people are not thinking that cows can be a part of the solution.WEIR (on camera): Not only are you going against the grain of environmentalists who think meat is evil for lots of reasons -

utterances.speaker: BYCK
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: You took money from McDonald's for this.

utterances.speaker: BYCK
utterances.sentences: Yes. I asked for money from McDonald's for this. I - I wanted to go to big companies because if they don't change, we don't get there.WEIR (voice over): For his docuseries, "Roots So Deep You Can See the Devil Down There," Byck assembled a team of scientists.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We're really interested in insects that live in poop.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Experts in bugs, birds --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, bob white!

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Cows, soils, and carbon. They spent years comparing five sets of neighboring farms in the southeast. On one side, traditional grazers who let cows roam one big field for months at a time and often cut fertilized grass for hay.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Whoo! Come on!

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: On the other side, amp grazers who never mow or fertilize.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You open a gate. They go through. It takes five minutes. Cooper will roll up a wire.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: And with a single line of electrical fence, move their cows from one patch of high grass to the next.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And that's building fence. This is how easy it is, Peter.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: While their science is yet to be published and peer reviewed, Byck says early data has found amp farms pulling down up to four times the carbon, while holding 25 percent more microbes, three times the bird life, and twice as much rain per hour.

utterances.speaker: BYCK
utterances.sentences: If it's a thousand-acre farm, it's 54 million gallons of water that's now washing your soil away versus soaking into your land. UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: But this is also a human experiment, to see whether data and respectful discussion can change hearts and minds.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This was grazed about 40 days ago and this hadn't been fertilized in 12 years.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Awesome.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And when we got out of spending money on fertilizer, it was huge. Huge. And I didn't think it would ever happen.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: It is such a stress relief. We just don't worry about a lot of it anymore.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: And you don't even fertilize when you plant your rye grass.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Nothing. It sounds crazy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: But it works.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: But just letting mother nature do the work.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Take it. Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Would it be an interesting thing if you didn't have to pay for fertilizer?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Wouldn't that be wonderful.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Curtis Spangler is one of the conventional farmers in "Roots So Deep," and he says his mind was changed when he realized he now has a way to double his herd and quit his second off-farm job.

utterances.speaker: CURTIS SPANGLER, TENNESSEE FARMER
utterances.sentences: And right now we're having to dump thousands of dollars into nitrogen every year that really, if we just change a couple things, might be able to save that money to put it toward other resources.WEIR (on camera): Is that something you're committed to doing now as a result of this project?

utterances.speaker: SPANGLER
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. We're - yes. We're really looking and seeing the benefits of it and how we can work it.WEIR (voice over): So, as we hit the height of grilling season, a little food for thought.

utterances.speaker: BYCK
utterances.sentences: There is ways to produce meat that is not good for the planet. And there's ways to produce meat that's really good for the planet. And that's the nuance that's been missing.(END VIDEOTAPE) WEIR: My little boy has a farm puzzle, you know, with the one pig and the one cow and the one chicken and this idyllic scene. And we don't realize that that is so far from what we have now. It's either big farms that are massive or they go out of business.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Or we do, but we've embraced mass production, right?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: I mean does this affect kind of our ability to kind of provide the nation agriculturally?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: They would say it absolutely does. That grass could replace feed lots if -- as a - as a disrupter, a cheaper alternative. But going against the -- these ideas is a massive, big ag industry. Fertilizers, big machinery, all of that, because all of the solutions are natural.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Do they have a plan to scale?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Well, this is early. This is just like, let's see if we can convince farmers across the fence to talk to each other.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: That's what's so heart-warming about this - this series. You've got two of the pairs actually are two founding members of the country band Alabama.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: Randy Owen is a traditional grazer, Teddy Gentry's been an amp farmer his whole life.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: And comparing -- and they don't talk to each other about it. You know, these are proud folks who work the land and don't really discuss their -- but this is really an interesting look at breaking common ground could be a solution for everybody. Healthier cows, land, birds, people, farmers, bottom lines.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: I love learning about the culture of this.Bill Weir, thank you.

utterances.speaker: WEIR
utterances.sentences: My pleasure.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: The Supreme Court's ruling to strike down President Biden's student loan forgiveness plan isn't just a blow to borrowers. Financial experts say it could have a significant impact on the nation's economy. In a ruling handed down Friday, the justices decided 6-3 against the president's plan. Now, it would have forgiven up to $20,000 in student loan debt for millions, up to 40 million, borrowers.CNN business correspondent Rahel Solomon is here. And, Rahel, this is actually -- I'm stoked you're doing this because there is a macro effect to this decision. It's not just about the politics or individual loans. There is an economic effect. What is it?

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes, though, isn't that the goal, right? The Fed has wanted to cool spending.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Well, whose goal?

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Whose goal? I mean that is the Fed's goal, absolutely, Audie.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Will the administration be crazy about consumer spending and the economy starting to lose steam in November? Not sure. Also, that's right before holiday shopping season. So there's a lot to consider here. But certainly for all of these people who suddenly have to make these payments again after three years, it's something that you're going to have to account for, literally.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes, if you were 21 when this went into place, that means you've never paid student loans. You all of a sudden have to figure out how to do it.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. There are a lot of people who will now have to pay student loans back for the first time, or they may have a completely different servicer. So there's - there's a lot at stake here.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: And spent several months expecting that a significant portion of their loans were going to be wiped away, and now --

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: That part.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Now, now not so much.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: So, there's another case we want to talk about because there are questions about the origin of the Supreme Court's ruling that sided with Colorado web designer Lorie Smith. So, the high court ruling, 6-3 on Friday, said that Smith can refuse to serve LGBTQ customers. And the man who Smith says contacted her for her services insists he never did, that the request was cited by her attorneys when the state of Colorado questioned whether she had grounds to sue. And what's more, the man who goes by Stewart says that he was not in a same-sex marriage. Telling CNN, I have never asked anybody to design a website for me, so it's all very strange. I certainly didn't contact her. And whatever the information in that request is, is fake.Joining us now also is CNN's senior legal analyst Elie Honig. Rahel is staying with us. So, I feel like on the way to a Supreme Court ruling, someone would have fact checked whether the names and places are who they say they are, et cetera. Tell us what happened here.

utterances.speaker: ELIE HONIG, CNN SENIOR LEGAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: Yes, one would think that the opposing party would do that. That the state of Colorado would do that. This is why the Supreme Court does not or did not, I should say, until last week, take hypotheticals, because the facts always matter. Even in the Supreme Court, with is all about the law, legalistic determinations, you have to know what the underlying facts are.And this is a core idea of jurisprudence. We don't take cases unless we have a full, factual record before us. What the Supreme Court did here is they found a way around that because they clearly wanted to take this case. They said, well, what we have is this web designer saying, yes, she's going to go into business and not going to make websites -- doesn't want to make websites for same-sex couples. And the state of Colorado saying, and we are going to enforce this law, therefore we have a sort of inevitable conflict. But here's the problem. Could end up your facts are wrong. Could end up your facts are distorted. Your --

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: But it doesn't actually disturb the results of the case in the end?

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: It's not going to cause a change in this case because they found this sort of backdoor to take the case. And it's so important because the Supreme Court is telling us we're going to be much more aggressive, we're going to be reaching down and taking more cases now.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Elie Honig, thank you.Rahel Solomon, thank you for being here.

utterances.speaker: SOLOMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, guys.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: All right, just revealed this morning, Argentine soccer star Lionel Messi will earn between $50 million and $60 million a year when he joins Inter Miami according to the club's part owner. The lower of those figures would make Messi the highest paid player in Major League Soccer by more than $40 million. That's some good delta right there. Messi also has the guarantee of being part of the club's ownership once he retires and, I think this is most important, gets a cut from the MLS broadcasting deal with Apple TV. Messi's long-time rival, Cristiano Ronaldo, has a $75 million salary -- playing salary playing for the Saudi Pro League.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Now for your "Morning Moment." Taylor Swift reacting swiftly after -- you see what we did there -

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: After an apparent stage malfunction during her Eras Tour stop in Cincinnati. Here is a look.(VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: I mean (ph) - look, not all heroes wear capes.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Are you - are you a huge - you're a huge Swiftie fan.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: I'm -- she's putting on four-hour shows. So, there's got to be a thing here or there.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I'm not - that was not me challenging her.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not saying, I'm just sticking up for the Swifties.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Why are you sticking -- no one's attacking them. There's no reason -

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: I mean, there's always someone.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: OK, but like not anybody who doesn't want to be attacked.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Have you listened to "Reputation?" The woman's got enemies.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Elie, your thoughts on Taylor Swift's enemies?

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: First of all --

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes, Elie, what does this mean for Trump?

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Well, first - first of all, I'm a "1989" guy when it comes to Taylor Swift.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Love it. Love it.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Second of all, let's - to be serious, she is fast. Like, she has good wheels there. She's moving.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: I think it's - I think it's leg length, like stride.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: And she's - I think she's wearing gigantic shoes, too.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: So give her credit. She's a Philadelphia Eagles fan, by the way. We need a kick returner.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: I feel like she only did that because she had a show (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: She is committed to the show and I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Elie, my guys, thank you.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HONIG
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: MATTINGLY
utterances.sentences: Audie, you want to hang out again tomorrow?

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes, thank you. I'd love to come back.
